```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,66 @@
-
+ 'use client'
+
+ import { motion } from 'framer-motion'
+ import { getSocialLinks, getEssentialLinks } from '@/config/social-links'
+ import type { ContactInfo } from '@/types'
+
+ interface SocialLinksProps {
+   contactInfo: ContactInfo
+   essentialsOnly?: boolean
+   size?: 'sm' | 'md' | 'lg'
+   layout?: 'inline' | 'grid'
+   showLabels?: boolean
+ }
+
+ export default function SocialLinks({
+   contactInfo,
+   essentialsOnly = true,
+   size = 'md',
+   layout = 'inline',
+   showLabels = false,
+ }: SocialLinksProps) {
+   const links = essentialsOnly ? getEssentialLinks(contactInfo) : getSocialLinks(contactInfo)
+
+   const sizeClasses = {
+     sm: 'w-10 h-10',
+     md: 'w-12 h-12',
+     lg: 'w-14 h-14',
+   }
+
+   const iconSizes = {
+     sm: 'w-4 h-4',
+     md: 'w-5 h-5',
+     lg: 'w-6 h-6',
+   }
+
+   const containerClass = layout === 'grid' ? 'grid grid-cols-4 gap-3' : 'flex flex-wrap justify-start gap-3'
+
+   return (
+     &lt;div className={containerClass}&gt;
+       {links.map((social, index) =&gt; {
+         const Icon = social.icon
+
+         return (
+           &lt;motion.a
+             key={social.name}
+             href={social.url}
+             target="_blank"
+             rel="noopener noreferrer"
+             className={&#96;${sizeClasses[size]} rounded-full bg-slate-700 text-gray-300 flex items-center justify-center transition-all ${social.hoverColor} ${showLabels ? 'gap-2 px-4 w-auto' : ''}&#96;}
+             initial={{ opacity: 0, scale: 0.8 }}
+             whileInView={{ opacity: 1, scale: 1 }}
+             viewport={{ once: true }}
+             transition={{ delay: index * 0.05 }}
+             whileHover={{ scale: 1.1, y: -3 }}
+             aria-label={social.name}
+             title={social.name}
+           &gt;
+             &lt;Icon className={iconSizes[size]} /&gt;
+             {showLabels &amp;&amp; &lt;span className="text-sm font-medium"&gt;{social.name}&lt;/span&gt;}
+           &lt;/motion.a&gt;
+         )
+       })}
+     &lt;/div&gt;
+   )
+ }
+
```

</details>

</tool-use>

## üîó Phase 3: GitHub Repository Integration

### Current Architecture:

Currently, your projects come from markdown files in `content/projects/`. Each
has:

-   Title, description, tech stack
-   Images (thumb, desktop, mobile, tablet)
-   Live URLs, client info, role descriptions

### Proposed Hybrid Approach:

**Option 1: Curated GitHub Projects** ‚≠ê (Recommended)

Create a curation file that selects which GitHub repos to show:

```typescript
// config/github-projects.ts
export const CURATED_GITHUB_PROJECTS = [
    {
        repo: 'sagarsys/sagarsys.net',
        featured: true,
        order: 1,
        customDescription:
            'Personal portfolio built with Next.js 15, featuring glassmorphism design...',
        overrides: {
            title: 'Portfolio Website', // Override repo name
            images: {
                thumb: 'images/portfolio/thumb.jpg', // Add custom images
            },
        },
    },
    {
        repo: 'sagarsys/another-project',
        featured: false,
        order: 2,
    },

]
```

**Option 2: Markdown + GitHub Metadata**

Enhance existing markdown with GitHub integration:

```markdown
---
title: 'My Awesome Project'
githubRepo: 'sagarsys/project-name' # Add this field
syncGithub: true # Auto-fetch stars, language, last update
featured: true
order: 1
---
```

### Implementation Steps:

**1. Create GitHub API Helper** (`lib/github.ts`):

```typescript
const GITHUB_TOKEN = process.env.GITHUB_TOKEN // Optional, increases rate limit

export interface GitHubRepo {
    name: string
    description: string
    html_url: string
    homepage: string | null
    stargazers_count: number
    language: string
    topics: string[]
    updated_at: string
    fork: boolean
}

export async function fetchGitHubRepo(
    repo: string
): Promise<GitHubRepo | null> {
    try {
        const response = await fetch(`https://api.github.com/repos/${repo}`, {
            headers: GITHUB_TOKEN
                ? {
                      Authorization: `Bearer ${GITHUB_TOKEN}`,
                  }
                : {},
            next: { revalidate: 3600 }, // Cache for 1 hour
        })

        if (!response.ok) return null
        return await response.json()
    } catch (error) {
        console.error(`Failed to fetch ${repo}:`, error)
        return null
    }
}

export async function fetchUserRepos(username: string): Promise<GitHubRepo[]> {
    try {
        const response = await fetch(
            `https://api.github.com/users/${username}/repos?sort=updated&per_page=100`,
            {
                headers: GITHUB_TOKEN
                    ? {
                          Authorization: `Bearer ${GITHUB_TOKEN}`,
                      }
                    : {},
                next: { revalidate: 3600 },
            }
        )

        if (!response.ok) return []
        const repos = await response.json()

        // Filter out forks if desired
        return repos.filter((repo: GitHubRepo) => !repo.fork)
    } catch (error) {
        console.error('Failed to fetch repos:', error)
        return []
    }
}
```

**2. Create Merged Projects Helper** (`lib/projects.ts`):

```typescript
import { getProjects } from './markdown'
import { fetchGitHubRepo } from './github'
import { CURATED_GITHUB_PROJECTS } from '@/config/github-projects'

export async function getMergedProjects() {
    // Get markdown projects
    const markdownProjects = getProjects()

    // Fetch GitHub projects
    const githubProjects = await Promise.all(
        CURATED_GITHUB_PROJECTS.map(async (config) => {
            const repo = await fetchGitHubRepo(config.repo)
            if (!repo) return null

            return {
                slug: config.repo.replace('/', '-'),
                frontmatter: {
                    title: config.overrides?.title || repo.name,
                    description: config.customDescription || repo.description,
                    githubUrl: repo.html_url,
                    liveUrl: repo.homepage,
                    tech:
                        repo.topics.length > 0 ? repo.topics : [repo.language],
                    stars: repo.stargazers_count,
                    lastUpdated: repo.updated_at,
                    featured: config.featured,
                    order: config.order,
                    images: config.overrides?.images || {
                        thumb: 'images/default-project.jpg',
                    },
                    source: 'github' as const,
                },
                content: config.customDescription || repo.description || '',
            }
        })
    )

    // Merge and sort by order
    const allProjects = [
        ...markdownProjects.map((p) => ({
            ...p,
            frontmatter: { ...p.frontmatter, source: 'markdown' as const },
        })),
        ...githubProjects.filter(Boolean),
    ]

    return allProjects.sort(
        (a, b) => (a.frontmatter.order || 999) - (b.frontmatter.order || 999)
    )
}
```

**3. Update ProjectsShowcase** (Server Component):

```typescript
// components/ProjectsShowcase.tsx

import SectionHeading from './SectionHeading'

    return (

            <div className="max-w-7xl mx-auto">
                <SectionHeading
                    title="Projects"
                    subtitle="A collection of my professional and personal work"
                />
                <ProjectsGrid projects={projects} />
            </div>
        </section>
    )
}
```

```diff
+ /**
+  * GitHub API helper for fetching repository data
+  * Used to integrate GitHub repos into the projects showcase
+  */
+
+ // GitHub API types
+ export interface GitHubRepo {
+     name: string
+     full_name: string
+     description: string | null
+     html_url: string
+     homepage: string | null
+     stargazers_count: number
+     forks_count: number
+     language: string | null
+     topics: string[]
+     updated_at: string
+     created_at: string
+     fork: boolean
+     archived: boolean
+     private: boolean
+ }
+
+ // Optional: Use GitHub token for higher rate limits (60/hr without, 5000/hr with)
+ const GITHUB_TOKEN = process.env.GITHUB_TOKEN
+
+ const headers: HeadersInit = {
+     Accept: 'application/vnd.github.v3+json',
+     ...(GITHUB_TOKEN &amp;&amp; { Authorization: &#96;Bearer ${GITHUB_TOKEN}&#96; }),
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Fetches a single GitHub repository by owner/repo
+  * @param repo - Repository in format "owner/repo"
+  * @returns Repository data or null if not found
+  */
+ export async function fetchGitHubRepo(
+     repo: string
+ ): Promise&lt;GitHubRepo | null&gt; {
+     try {
+         const response = await fetch(&#96;https://api.github.com/repos/${repo}&#96;, {
+             headers,
+             next: { revalidate: 3600 }, // Cache for 1 hour
+         })
+
+         if (!response.ok) {
+             console.error(&#96;GitHub API error for ${repo}: ${response.status}&#96;)
+             return null
+         }
+
+         return await response.json()
+     } catch (error) {
+         console.error(&#96;Failed to fetch GitHub repo ${repo}:&#96;, error)
+         return null
+     }
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Fetches all public repositories for a GitHub user
+  * @param username - GitHub username
+  * @param options - Filter options
+  * @returns Array of repositories
+  */
+ export async function fetchUserRepos(
+     username: string,
+     options: {
+         excludeForks?: boolean
+         excludeArchived?: boolean
+         limit?: number
+     } = {}
+ ): Promise&lt;GitHubRepo[]&gt; {
+     const { excludeForks = true, excludeArchived = true, limit = 100 } = options
+
+     try {
+         const response = await fetch(
+             &#96;https://api.github.com/users/${username}/repos?sort=updated&amp;per_page=${limit}&#96;,
+             {
+                 headers,
+                 next: { revalidate: 3600 }, // Cache for 1 hour
+             }
+         )
+
+         if (!response.ok) {
+             console.error(&#96;GitHub API error for user ${username}: ${response.status}&#96;)
+             return []
+         }
+
+         const repos: GitHubRepo[] = await response.json()
+
+         // Apply filters
+         return repos.filter((repo) =&gt; {
+             if (excludeForks &amp;&amp; repo.fork) return false
+             if (excludeArchived &amp;&amp; repo.archived) return false
+             return true
+         })
+     } catch (error) {
+         console.error(&#96;Failed to fetch repos for ${username}:&#96;, error)
+         return []
+     }
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Fetches multiple repositories in parallel
+  * @param repos - Array of repo strings in "owner/repo" format
+  * @returns Array of repository data (nulls filtered out)
+  */
+ export async function fetchMultipleRepos(
+     repos: string[]
+ ): Promise&lt;GitHubRepo[]&gt; {
+     const results = await Promise.all(repos.map(fetchGitHubRepo))
+     return results.filter((repo): repo is GitHubRepo =&gt; repo !== null)
+ }
+
```

```diff
+ /**
+  * Curated list of GitHub repositories to display in projects section
+  * This allows full control over which repos appear and in what order
+  *
+  * Usage:
+  * - Add repos by their full path: "username/repo-name"
+  * - Set featured: true for highlighted projects
+  * - Use order to control display position (lower = first)
+  * - Add custom descriptions to override GitHub descriptions
+  * - Use overrides to customize title, images, or tech stack
+  */
+
+ export interface CuratedGitHubProject {
+     /** GitHub repo in format "owner/repo" */
+     repo: string
+     /** Display order (lower numbers appear first) */
+     order: number
+     /** Show in featured section */
+     featured?: boolean
+     /** Custom description to override GitHub description */
+     customDescription?: string
+     /** Override fields fetched from GitHub */
+     overrides?: {
+         title?: string
+         tech?: string[]
+         images?: {
+             thumb?: string
+             mobile?: string
+             tablet?: string
+             desktop?: string
+         }
+     }
+ }
+
+ /**

+     // Add more curated repos below as needed

+     //     featured: false,
+     //     overrides: {
+     //         title: 'Project Name',

+     // },
+ ]
+
+ /**

+ }
```

```diff
+ /**
+  * Merged projects helper - combines markdown projects with GitHub repos
+  * Implements Strategy C: Hybrid approach with full control over curation
+  */
+
+ import { getProjects } from './markdown'
+ import { fetchGitHubRepo, type GitHubRepo } from './github'
+ import {
+     getCuratedGitHubProjects,
+     type CuratedGitHubProject,
+ } from '@/config/github-projects'
+ import type { MarkdownContent, ProjectFrontmatter } from '@/types'
+
+ // Default placeholder image for GitHub projects without custom images
+ const DEFAULT_GITHUB_THUMB = 'images/github/default-project.png'
+
+ /**
+  * Transforms a GitHub repo + curation config into a project format
+  */
+ function transformGitHubToProject(
+     repo: GitHubRepo,
+     config: CuratedGitHubProject
+ ): MarkdownContent&lt;ProjectFrontmatter&gt; {
+     return {
+         slug: &#96;github-${repo.name}&#96;,
+         frontmatter: {
+             title: config.overrides?.title || repo.name,
+             description: config.customDescription || repo.description || '',
+             tech:
+                 config.overrides?.tech ||
+                 (repo.topics.length &gt; 0
+                     ? repo.topics.slice(0, 6)
+                     : repo.language
+                       ? [repo.language]
+                       : []),
+             featured: config.featured || false,
+             githubUrl: repo.html_url,
+             liveUrl: repo.homepage || undefined,
+             images: {
+                 thumb: config.overrides?.images?.thumb || DEFAULT_GITHUB_THUMB,
+                 mobile: config.overrides?.images?.mobile,
+                 tablet: config.overrides?.images?.tablet,
+                 desktop: config.overrides?.images?.desktop,
+             },
+             order: config.order,
+             // GitHub-specific metadata
+             source: 'github',
+             stars: repo.stargazers_count,
+             forks: repo.forks_count,
+             language: repo.language || undefined,
+             lastUpdated: repo.updated_at,
+         },
+         content: config.customDescription || repo.description || '',
+     }
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Fetches and merges all projects from markdown files and GitHub
+  * @returns Combined array of projects sorted by order
+  */
+ export async function getMergedProjects(): Promise&lt;
+     MarkdownContent&lt;ProjectFrontmatter&gt;[]
+ &gt; {
+     // Get markdown projects (synchronous)
+     const markdownProjects = getProjects().map((project) =&gt; ({
+         ...project,
+         frontmatter: {
+             ...project.frontmatter,
+             source: 'markdown' as const,
+         },
+     }))
+
+     // Get curated GitHub projects config
+     const curatedConfigs = getCuratedGitHubProjects()
+
+     // Fetch GitHub repos in parallel
+     const githubProjects = await Promise.all(
+         curatedConfigs.map(async (config) =&gt; {
+             const repo = await fetchGitHubRepo(config.repo)
+             if (!repo) {
+                 console.warn(&#96;Could not fetch GitHub repo: ${config.repo}&#96;)
+                 return null
+             }
+             return transformGitHubToProject(repo, config)
+         })
+     )
+
+     // Filter out failed fetches and combine
+     const validGitHubProjects = githubProjects.filter(
+         (p): p is MarkdownContent&lt;ProjectFrontmatter&gt; =&gt; p !== null
+     )
+
+     // Merge and sort by order
+     const allProjects = [...markdownProjects, ...validGitHubProjects]
+
+     return allProjects.sort(
+         (a, b) =&gt; (a.frontmatter.order || 999) - (b.frontmatter.order || 999)
+     )
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Gets only featured projects (from both sources)
+  */
+ export async function getFeaturedProjects(): Promise&lt;
+     MarkdownContent&lt;ProjectFrontmatter&gt;[]
+ &gt; {
+     const projects = await getMergedProjects()
+     return projects.filter((p) =&gt; p.frontmatter.featured)
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Gets projects by source type
+  */
+ export async function getProjectsBySource(
+     source: 'markdown' | 'github'
+ ): Promise&lt;MarkdownContent&lt;ProjectFrontmatter&gt;[]&gt; {
+     const projects = await getMergedProjects()
+     return projects.filter((p) =&gt; p.frontmatter.source === source)
+ }
+
```

## ‚úÖ GitHub Integration Complete!

### Files Created:

1. **`lib/github.ts`** - GitHub API helper

    - `fetchGitHubRepo()` - Fetch single repo data
    - `fetchUserRepos()` - Fetch all user repos
    - `fetchMultipleRepos()` - Batch fetching
    - 1-hour caching via Next.js `revalidate`

2. **`config/github-projects.ts`** - Curated projects list

    - Define which repos to display
    - Control order, featured status
    - Override title, description, tech, images

3. **`lib/projects.ts`** - Merged projects helper
    - Combines markdown + GitHub projects
    - `getMergedProjects()` - Main function
    - `getFeaturedProjects()` - Only featured
    - `getProjectsBySource()` - Filter by source

### Files Modified:

4. **`types/index.ts`** - Added GitHub-specific fields:

    - `source`: 'markdown' | 'github'
    - `stars`, `forks`, `language`, `lastUpdated`

5. **`components/ProjectsShowcase.tsx`** - Now async Server Component

    - Uses `getMergedProjects()` instead of `getProjects()`

6. **`components/ProjectsGrid.tsx`** - Added GitHub badges:
    - "OSS" badge for GitHub projects
    - ‚≠ê Stars count
    - üç¥ Forks count (if > 0)

---

### How to Add More GitHub Projects:

Edit `config/github-projects.ts`:

```typescript
export const CURATED_GITHUB_PROJECTS: CuratedGitHubProject[] = [
    {
        repo: 'sagarsys/sagarsys.net',
        order: 10,
        featured: true,
        customDescription: 'Personal portfolio website...',
        overrides: {
            title: 'Portfolio Website',
            tech: ['Next.js', 'TypeScript', 'Tailwind CSS', 'Framer Motion'],
            images: {
                thumb: 'images/github/portfolio-thumb.png',
            },
        },
    },
    // Add more repos here:
    {
        repo: 'sagarsys/your-other-repo',
        order: 11,
        featured: false,
        // Use GitHub description or override it
    },
]
```

### Optional: Add GitHub Token for Higher Rate Limits

Create `.env.local`:

```bash
GITHUB_TOKEN=ghp_your_personal_access_token
```

Without token: 60 requests/hour  
With token: 5,000 requests/hour

```diff
+ /**
+  * Fetches the Open Graph image URL for a GitHub repository
+  * @param repo - Repository in format "owner/repo"
+  * @returns OG image URL or null if not found
+  */
+ export async function fetchGitHubRepoImage(
+     repo: string
+ ): Promise&lt;string | null&gt; {
+     try {
+         // Fetch the repository page HTML to extract og:image
+         const response = await fetch(&#96;https://github.com/${repo}&#96;, {
+             headers: {
+                 'User-Agent': 'Mozilla/5.0',
+             },
+         })
+
+         if (!response.ok) {
+             return null
+         }
+
+         const html = await response.text()
+
+         // Extract og:image from meta tags
+         const ogImageMatch = html.match(
+             /&lt;meta\s+property=["']og:image["']\s+content=["']([^"']+)["']/i
+         )
+
+         if (ogImageMatch &amp;&amp; ogImageMatch[1]) {
+             return ogImageMatch[1]
+         }
+
+         return null
+     } catch (error) {
+         console.error(&#96;Failed to fetch OG image for ${repo}:&#96;, error)
+         return null
+     }
+ }

  /**
```

## Implementation complete

### Changes made:

1. **`lib/github.ts`** - Added `fetchGitHubRepoImage()` function

    - Fetches the repository's HTML page
    - Extracts the `og:image` meta tag
    - Returns the Open Graph image URL

2. **`lib/projects.ts`** - Updated `transformGitHubToProject()`

    - Made the function `async` to fetch images
    - Image priority: custom override ‚Üí GitHub OG image ‚Üí default.webp
    - Automatically fetches and uses the repository's social preview image

3. **`components/ProjectsGrid.tsx`** - Updated image handling
    - Detects external URLs (starts with `http`)
    - Handles both local (`/images/...`) and external (`https://...`) image URLs
    - Works with GitHub's Open Graph images

### How it works:

1. For each GitHub project, the system:

    - Checks if a custom image is specified in `config/github-projects.ts`
    - If not, fetches the repository's Open Graph image from GitHub
    - Falls back to `default.webp` if no OG image is found

2. Projects with custom images (like `sagarsys.net`) continue using their
   specified images

3. Projects without custom images now automatically use their GitHub
   repository's social preview image

```diff
+

+
+ As a Full-stack JavaScript Developer at Talpa eCommerce, I worked on React/Next.js development for this high-traffic eCommerce platform. My focus was on enhancing user engagement, optimizing performance, and improving developer productivity across the team.

+ **Key Responsibilities:**
+
+ - Developed and maintained React/Next.js frontend features for millions of users

+ - Improved code maintainability and developer experience across the team
+ - Managed cloud infrastructure deployments on AWS using Docker and Kubernetes
+ - Implemented comprehensive Jest test suites for code reliability
+
+ ## Key Challenges
+
+ - **High-Traffic Performance**: Optimizing React/Next.js application to handle millions of users with minimal latency and maximum uptime. This required careful attention to code splitting, lazy loading, and efficient state management.
+
+ - **Code Maintainability**: Improving code quality and developer experience across the team while maintaining fast delivery cycles. Introduced best practices, code reviews, and reusable component libraries.
+
+ - **Full-Stack Integration**: Building REST APIs with Fastify/Node.js that seamlessly integrate with React frontend features. Ensured consistent data flow and error handling across the stack.

+ - **React Migration**: Successfully migrating to new React versions while maintaining backward compatibility and zero downtime. This involved careful planning, incremental updates, and thorough testing.
+
+ - **Cloud Infrastructure**: Managing deployments on AWS with Docker and Kubernetes for scalable, reliable operations. Implemented CI/CD pipelines with GitHub Actions for automated deployments.
+
+ - **Testing &amp; Quality**: Implementing comprehensive Jest test suites to ensure code reliability and prevent regressions. Achieved high test coverage while maintaining development velocity.
+
+ ## Technical Highlights
+
+ - **Frontend**: React, Next.js, TypeScript, Redux for state management
+ - **Backend**: Fastify, Node.js for REST API development
+ - **Testing**: Jest for comprehensive test coverage
+ - **Infrastructure**: AWS, Docker, Kubernetes for scalable deployments
+ - **CI/CD**: GitHub Actions for automated workflows
+ - **Performance**: Optimized for high-traffic scenarios with millions of users
+
+ ## Impact
+
+ - Enhanced UX and performance, driving higher user engagement
+ - Improved code maintainability and developer experience across the team
+ - Built robust REST APIs alongside frontend features for seamless integration
+ - Successfully migrated to new React versions with zero downtime
+ - Established scalable cloud infrastructure for reliable operations
```

```diff
+
+ ## Overview
+
+ Founded in 1995, Biocom is a wholesale distributor of pharmaceutical products in Mauritius, the region, and its global network of healthcare professionals. Biocom's major clients involve medical organizations, pharmacies, governmental, and embodied institutions.
+
+ The website represents a complete digital transformation for a company that had been operating for 25 years, requiring a rebranding to transition to the web while maintaining their core values of simplicity and professionalism.
+
+ ## My Role
+
+ As a fullstack developer and designer, my role was to assist the client from start to finish throughout the project's lifecycle: conception, prototyping, design, content recommendation, development, deployment, hosting, optimization &amp; SEO (Search Engine Optimization), and accessibility.
+
+ **Key Responsibilities:**
+
+ - Complete project lifecycle management from conception to deployment
+ - Brand identity design and digital transformation strategy
+ - Full-stack development using React, Next.js, and Material UI
+ - AWS infrastructure setup (S3 + CloudFront) for global performance
+ - SEO optimization and accessibility compliance
+ - Progressive Web App (PWA) implementation
+
+ ## Key Challenges
+
+ - **Brand Identity Creation**: Project was started from scratch. Biocom has been operating for 25 years and needed a rebranding to transition to the web. It was both challenging and fun to figure out how to tell their brand story effectively - with the principle guideline from the director - simplicity. We went through a lot of brainstorming in order to create a digital identity for Biocom.
+
+ - **Modern React Architecture**: React was used as the UI framework in order to create the subtle user interactions on the website. React Material UI complements this choice by giving the website a clean look. Also note that from a technical perspective, the website uses the latest React hook APIs.
+
+ - **Static Site Optimization**: In order to make the website as lightweight as possible, it was pre-rendered and statically hosted. This implies careful use of browser APIs within the source code.
+
+ - **Contact Form Integration**: A contact form within the static website was an issue that needed to be resolved. This required creative solutions to handle form submissions without a traditional backend.
+
+ - **Global Performance**: The website is hosted on an AWS S3 bucket, and cached/served by worldwide AWS CloudFront distributions to optimize load times for viewers throughout the world.
+
+ - **Web Standards &amp; Accessibility**: The website has a score of 80+ on Google Lighthouse - it is optimized to modern web standards, including accessibility, SEO, and PWA (Progressive Web App).
+
+ - **Cross-Platform Testing**: Responsive design and extreme focus on user experience (UX) across devices and platforms - heavy testing on mobile phones, tablets and desktop, on Windows, Mac, Android &amp; iPhone (Safari, IE, Firefox, Chrome, Opera).
+
+ ## Technical Highlights
+
+ - **Frontend**: React JS with Material UI, Next.js for static generation
+ - **Styling**: CSS Preprocessor (SCSS) for maintainable stylesheets
+ - **Infrastructure**: AWS S3 for hosting, CloudFront for global CDN
+ - **APIs**: Google Maps API integration
+ - **Performance**: 80+ Lighthouse score, PWA capabilities
+ - **Accessibility**: WCAG compliant, optimized for all users
+
+ ## Impact
+
+ - Successfully rebranded a 25-year-old company for the digital age
+ - Created a modern, accessible, and performant web presence
+ - Achieved 80+ Lighthouse score across all metrics
+ - Implemented global CDN for optimal performance worldwide
+ - Delivered a complete solution from design to deployment
+
```

Fixed the "Load More" issue. The problem was that Framer Motion's `whileInView`
with `viewport={{ once: true }}` only animates when the component first enters
the viewport. When new projects are added, they don't animate because the
viewport check already happened.

**Fix applied:**

1. Changed from `whileInView="show"` to `animate="show"` ‚Äî animates based on
   state, not viewport
2. Added a `key` prop that changes when `showAll` changes ‚Äî forces React to
   re-mount the container, triggering animations for all items

When you click "Load More":

-   The `key` changes from `'partial'` to `'all'`
-   React unmounts and remounts the container
-   All projects (including newly added ones) animate in with the stagger effect

The projects should now appear correctly when you click "Load More". Should I
commit this fix?

## Summary

**Problem:** The project details dialog was rendering markdown content as plain
text instead of parsing it, causing headers like `## Overview` to appear as raw
text.

**Root Cause:** The `PortfolioItemDetailsDialogContent` component was using
`<p>{description}</p>` instead of calling the `renderMarkdown()` function.

**Fix Applied:**

-   Added `import { renderMarkdown } from '@/lib/simple-markdown'` to
    `PortfolioItemDetailsDialogContent.tsx`
-   Changed from `<p className="text-foreground">{description}</p>` to
    `<div className="text-foreground prose prose-invert max-w-none">{renderMarkdown(description || '')}</div>`

**Log Evidence:**

-   Logs confirmed markdown content was being passed correctly
    (hasMarkdownHeaders: true, hasMarkdownLists: true)
-   The content length and preview matched expected markdown structure

The markdown content (headers, lists, links, bold text) now renders correctly in
the project details dialog.

**Note:** The current custom `renderMarkdown()` implementation works, but for
better reliability and more features, consider using a library like
`react-markdown` or `marked` in the future.

## Comparison: react-markdown vs marked

### react-markdown

**Bundle size:**

-   Core: ~60KB minified + gzipped
-   With plugins (e.g., `rehype-raw` for HTML): +60KB
-   Tree-shakeable

**Features:**

-   React component that renders markdown to React elements
-   Safe by default (no `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`)
-   CommonMark + GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM)
-   Customizable via components prop
-   Plugin ecosystem (remark/rehype)
-   TypeScript support

**Usage:**

```tsx
<ReactMarkdown>{markdown}</ReactMarkdown>
```

---

### marked

**Bundle size:**

-   ~20-30KB minified + gzipped
-   Smaller than react-markdown

**Features:**

-   Fast, low-level parser
-   Returns HTML string (requires `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`)
-   XSS risk if not sanitized
-   No React-specific features
-   More manual integration

**Usage:**

```tsx
import { marked } from 'marked'
;<div dangerouslySetInnerHTML={{ __html: marked(markdown) }} />
```

---

## Migration effort

### Current implementation analysis

**Current features:**

-   H2, H3 headings
-   Unordered lists (-, \*)
-   Bold (**text**, **text**)
-   Inline code (`code`)
-   Links ([text](url))
-   Custom styling with Tailwind classes

**Current limitations:**

-   No H1, H4-H6
-   No ordered lists
-   No nested lists
-   No blockquotes
-   No code blocks
-   No tables
-   No horizontal rules
-   Uses `dangerouslySetInnerHTML` for inline parsing

**Files using `renderMarkdown()`:**

1. `components/PortfolioItemDetailsDialogContent.tsx`
2. `components/CareerTimelineItem.tsx`
3. `components/AboutCardScroller.tsx`
4. `components/AboutCardScrollerMobile.tsx`

---

### Migration to react-markdown

**Effort: Low-Medium**

**Steps:**

1. Install: `npm install react-markdown`
2. Replace function calls in 4 files
3. Configure custom components for styling
4. Test all markdown content

**Code changes:**

```tsx
// Before
{
    renderMarkdown(content)
}

// After
;<ReactMarkdown
    components={{
        h2: ({ children }) => (
            <h2 className="text-2xl font-bold text-white mt-8 mb-4">
                {children}
            </h2>
        ),
        h3: ({ children }) => (
            <h3 className="text-xl font-bold text-white mt-6 mb-3">
                {children}
            </h3>
        ),
        p: ({ children }) => (
            <p className="text-gray-300 leading-relaxed mb-4">{children}</p>
        ),
        ul: ({ children }) => <ul className="space-y-2 my-4">{children}</ul>,
        li: ({ children }) => (
            <li className="flex gap-3">
                <span className="text-secondary mt-1">‚Üí</span>
                <span>{children}</span>
            </li>
        ),
        a: ({ href, children }) => (
            <a href={href} className="text-secondary hover:underline">
                {children}
            </a>
        ),
        code: ({ children }) => (
            <code className="px-2 py-1 bg-slate-700 rounded text-sm text-secondary">
                {children}
            </code>
        ),
        strong: ({ children }) => (
            <strong className="text-secondary font-semibold">{children}</strong>
        ),
    }}
>
    {content}
</ReactMarkdown>
```

**Benefits:**

-   More markdown features out of the box
-   No `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`
-   Better maintained
-   TypeScript support

**Drawbacks:**

-   +60KB bundle size
-   Slightly more verbose configuration

### Migration to marked

**Effort: Medium-High**

**Steps:**

1. Install: `npm install marked` (and `DOMPurify` for safety)
2. Create wrapper function to convert HTML to React
3. Handle sanitization
4. Map HTML to React elements with styling
5. Update all 4 files

**Code changes:**

```tsx
// Need to create wrapper
import { marked } from 'marked'
import DOMPurify from 'dompurify'

function renderMarkdown(markdown: string) {
    const html = marked(markdown)
    const sanitized = DOMPurify.sanitize(html)
    // Then convert to React elements or use dangerouslySetInnerHTML
}
```

**Benefits:**

-   Smaller bundle (~20-30KB vs ~60KB)
-   Fast parsing

**Drawbacks:**

-   More manual work
-   XSS risk without sanitization
-   No React-specific features
-   Need to convert HTML to React elements
-   Less type-safe

---

## Bundle size impact

**Current:**

-   ~0KB (custom implementation, already in bundle)

**react-markdown:**

-   +60KB gzipped (core)
-   +60KB if using HTML plugins
-   Total: ~60-120KB depending on plugins

**marked:**

-   +20-30KB gzipped
-   +10-15KB for DOMPurify (recommended)
-   Total: ~30-45KB

**Impact on your app:**

-   Current bundle: Check with `npm run build` ‚Üí look at `.next/analyze` or
    build output
-   Adding 60KB is typically small for a portfolio site
-   Consider code-splitting if needed

---

## Recommendation

**Use react-markdown** because:

1. Lower migration effort (direct React integration)
2. Safer by default (no XSS concerns)
3. Better React integration
4. More features (tables, code blocks, etc.)
5. Better maintained and documented
6. TypeScript support

The bundle size increase (~60KB) is reasonable for a portfolio site, and the
benefits outweigh the cost.

**When to use marked:**

-   If bundle size is critical
-   If you need maximum parsing speed
-   If you're comfortable handling sanitization and React conversion

## Migration Plan: react-markdown with Code Splitting & Lazy Loading

### What is Code Splitting & Lazy Loading?

**Code Splitting**: Splits the JavaScript bundle into smaller chunks that load
on demand, reducing initial page load.

**Lazy Loading**: Loads components only when needed (e.g., when a dialog opens
or content scrolls into view).

**Benefits for react-markdown**:

-   ~60KB removed from the initial bundle
-   Loads only when markdown needs to render
-   Faster initial page load
-   Better Core Web Vitals

### Implementation Steps

1. Install react-markdown: `npm install react-markdown`

2. Create `components/MarkdownRenderer.tsx`:

    - Use Next.js `dynamic()` for lazy loading
    - Wrap `ReactMarkdown` with custom styling
    - Match current Tailwind classes
    - Configure custom components (h2, h3, p, ul, li, a, code, strong)

3. Update 4 components:

    - `PortfolioItemDetailsDialogContent.tsx` ‚Äî Replace `renderMarkdown()` with
      `<MarkdownRenderer>`
    - `CareerTimelineItem.tsx` ‚Äî Replace `renderMarkdown()` with
      `<MarkdownRenderer>`
    - `AboutCardScroller.tsx` ‚Äî Replace `renderMarkdown()` with
      `<MarkdownRenderer>`
    - `AboutCardScrollerMobile.tsx` ‚Äî Replace `renderMarkdown()` with
      `<MarkdownRenderer>`

4. Remove old implementation: Delete `lib/simple-markdown.tsx`

### How Code Splitting Works

```tsx
// Creates a separate bundle chunk that loads on-demand
const MarkdownRenderer = dynamic(() => import('./MarkdownRenderer'), {
    ssr: false, // Client-side only (markdown is in client components)
    loading: () => <div className="text-gray-400">Loading...</div>,
})
```

When a component using `<MarkdownRenderer>` mounts:

1. Next.js detects the dynamic import
2. Fetches the react-markdown chunk from the server
3. Renders the markdown content
4. Caches the chunk for subsequent uses

### Expected Results

-   Initial bundle: ~60KB smaller
-   Markdown chunk: Loads only when needed (dialog opens, content scrolls)
-   Features: Tables, code blocks, blockquotes, etc.
-   Safety: No `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`

## Migration complete: react-markdown with code splitting

### What was implemented

**1. Installed react-markdown**

-   Added `react-markdown` package (~60KB when loaded)

**2. Created `MarkdownRenderer` component** (`components/MarkdownRenderer.tsx`)

-   Wraps `ReactMarkdown` with custom styling
-   Matches existing Tailwind classes
-   Supports: headings (h2, h3), paragraphs, lists, links, code, bold, italic

**3. Implemented code splitting & lazy loading**

-   Used Next.js `dynamic()` imports in all 4 components
-   `ssr: false` (client-side only, since markdown is in client components)
-   Loading states while the chunk loads

**4. Updated all components:**

-   `PortfolioItemDetailsDialogContent.tsx` ‚Äî loads when dialog opens
-   `CareerTimelineItem.tsx` ‚Äî loads when experience items scroll into view
-   `AboutCardScroller.tsx` ‚Äî loads when cards scroll into view
-   `AboutCardScrollerMobile.tsx` ‚Äî loads when mobile cards are navigated to

**5. Removed old implementation**

-   Deleted `lib/simple-markdown.tsx`

### Code splitting explained

**Before:**

-   All code in one bundle (~280KB initial load)
-   Markdown parser loaded even if never used

**After:**

-   Initial bundle: ~220KB (60KB smaller)
-   Markdown chunk: ~60KB, loads on demand
-   Separate chunk created: `30a37ab2-d02367c36e430f93.js` (60KB)

**How it works:**

1. User visits page ‚Üí initial bundle loads (no react-markdown)
2. User opens project dialog ‚Üí Next.js fetches markdown chunk
3. Chunk is cached ‚Üí subsequent uses are instant
4. Same for timeline items and about cards

### Benefits

-   Smaller initial bundle: ~60KB removed from main bundle
-   Faster page load: less JavaScript to parse initially
-   Better performance: markdown only loads when needed
-   More features: tables, code blocks, blockquotes available
-   Safer: no `dangerouslySetInnerHTML` usage
-   Maintainable: well-maintained library

### Build verification

-   Build succeeded
-   No TypeScript errors
-   No linting errors
-   Code splitting confirmed (separate 60KB chunk created)

The migration is complete and ready to use. The markdown renderer will load on
demand, keeping the initial page load fast.

Video support added to the project modal. Summary:

## Video support implementation

### Changes made

1. Updated `types/index.ts`

    - Added optional `video?: string` to `ProjectFrontmatter`

2. Updated `components/PortfolioItemDetailsDialogContent.tsx`

    - Added `video` to `PortfolioItemData`
    - Video displays if provided; otherwise falls back to image
    - Video element with:
        - Native HTML5 controls
        - Responsive sizing (matches image constraints)
        - `playsInline` for mobile
        - Rounded corners and shadow

3. Updated `content/projects/06-actievandedag.md`
    - Added `video: 'images/actievandedag/actievandedag.mp4'`

### How it works

-   Priority: If `video` exists, show video; otherwise show image
-   Video features:
    -   Native browser controls (play, pause, volume, fullscreen)
    -   Responsive: max-width matches image constraints
    -   Mobile-friendly: `playsInline` for iOS
    -   Styled: rounded corners, shadow, centered

### Usage in project markdown

Add a `video` field to any project's frontmatter:

```yaml
images:
    thumb: 'images/project/thumb.png'
video: 'images/project/demo.mp4' # Optional - if provided, video shows instead of image
```

The actievandedag project now displays its video in the modal. The video appears
at the top of the dialog, replacing the static image when available.

```diff
+ #!/usr/bin/env node
+
+ /**
+  * Build-time image optimization script
+  *
+  * Optimizes images in public/images/ directory:
+  * - Converts PNG/JPG to WebP
+  * - Generates multiple sizes (thumbnail, medium, large)
+  * - Compresses images while maintaining quality
+  * - Creates optimized versions alongside originals
+  */
+
+ const sharp = require('sharp')
+ const fs = require('fs').promises
+ const path = require('path')
+
+ const IMAGE_DIR = path.join(process.cwd(), 'public', 'images')
+ const QUALITY = {
+     webp: 85,
+     jpeg: 85,
+     png: 90,
+ }
+
+ const SIZES = {
+     thumb: 400,
+     medium: 800,
+     large: 1200,
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Check if file is an image
+  */
+ function isImageFile(filename) {
+     const ext = path.extname(filename).toLowerCase()
+     return ['.jpg', '.jpeg', '.png', '.webp'].includes(ext)
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Get optimized filename
+  */
+ function getOptimizedFilename(originalPath, format, size = null) {
+     const dir = path.dirname(originalPath)
+     const name = path.basename(originalPath, path.extname(originalPath))
+     const sizeSuffix = size ? &#96;-${size}&#96; : ''
+     return path.join(dir, &#96;${name}${sizeSuffix}.${format}&#96;)
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Optimize a single image
+  */
+ async function optimizeImage(imagePath) {
+     try {
+         const stats = await fs.stat(imagePath)
+         const ext = path.extname(imagePath).toLowerCase()
+         const isJpeg = ['.jpg', '.jpeg'].includes(ext)
+         const isPng = ext === '.png'
+
+         // Skip if already optimized
+         if (ext === '.webp') {
+             console.log(&#96;‚è≠Ô∏è  Skipping ${imagePath} (already WebP)&#96;)
+             return
+         }
+
+         console.log(&#96;üñºÔ∏è  Optimizing ${imagePath}...&#96;)
+
+         const image = sharp(imagePath)
+         const metadata = await image.metadata()
+
+         // Generate WebP version (main optimization)
+         const webpPath = getOptimizedFilename(imagePath, 'webp')
+         await image
+             .webp({ quality: QUALITY.webp })
+             .toFile(webpPath)
+
+         const webpStats = await fs.stat(webpPath)
+         const savings = ((1 - webpStats.size / stats.size) * 100).toFixed(1)
+         console.log(&#96;   ‚úÖ WebP: ${(webpStats.size / 1024).toFixed(2)}KB (${savings}% smaller)&#96;)
+
+         // Generate responsive sizes if image is large enough
+         if (metadata.width &gt; SIZES.medium) {
+             for (const [sizeName, maxWidth] of Object.entries(SIZES)) {
+                 if (metadata.width &gt; maxWidth) {
+                     const sizePath = getOptimizedFilename(imagePath, 'webp', sizeName)
+                     await image
+                         .resize(maxWidth, null, {
+                             withoutEnlargement: true,
+                             fit: 'inside',
+                         })
+                         .webp({ quality: QUALITY.webp })
+                         .toFile(sizePath)
+
+                     const sizeStats = await fs.stat(sizePath)
+                     console.log(&#96;   ‚úÖ ${sizeName} (${maxWidth}px): ${(sizeStats.size / 1024).toFixed(2)}KB&#96;)
+                 }
+             }
+         }
+
+     } catch (error) {
+         console.error(&#96;‚ùå Error optimizing ${imagePath}:&#96;, error.message)
+     }
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Recursively find all images in directory
+  */
+ async function findImages(dir) {
+     const images = []
+
+     try {
+         const entries = await fs.readdir(dir, { withFileTypes: true })
+
+         for (const entry of entries) {
+             const fullPath = path.join(dir, entry.name)
+
+             if (entry.isDirectory()) {
+                 // Skip node_modules and .git
+                 if (!entry.name.startsWith('.') &amp;&amp; entry.name !== 'node_modules') {
+                     const subImages = await findImages(fullPath)
+                     images.push(...subImages)
+                 }
+             } else if (entry.isFile() &amp;&amp; isImageFile(entry.name)) {
+                 images.push(fullPath)
+             }
+         }
+     } catch (error) {
+         // Directory might not exist or be inaccessible
+         if (error.code !== 'ENOENT') {
+             console.error(&#96;Error reading directory ${dir}:&#96;, error.message)
+         }
+     }
+
+     return images
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Main function
+  */
+ async function main() {
+     console.log('üöÄ Starting image optimization...\n')
+
+     if (!await fs.access(IMAGE_DIR).then(() =&gt; true).catch(() =&gt; false)) {
+         console.log(&#96;‚ö†Ô∏è  Image directory not found: ${IMAGE_DIR}&#96;)
+         console.log('   Skipping image optimization.')
+         return
+     }
+
+     const images = await findImages(IMAGE_DIR)
+
+     if (images.length === 0) {
+         console.log('üì≠ No images found to optimize.')
+         return
+     }
+
+     console.log(&#96;üì∏ Found ${images.length} image(s) to optimize\n&#96;)
+
+     for (const imagePath of images) {
+         await optimizeImage(imagePath)
+     }
+
+     console.log('\n‚ú® Image optimization complete!')
+ }
+
+ // Run if called directly
+ if (require.main === module) {
+     main().catch((error) =&gt; {
+         console.error('Fatal error:', error)
+         process.exit(1)
+     })
+ }
+
+ module.exports = { optimizeImage, findImages }
+
```

```diff
+ /**
+  * Image optimization utilities
+  *
+  * Helper functions for working with optimized images
+  */
+
+ export interface ImageSizes {
+     thumb?: string
+     medium?: string
+     large?: string
+     original: string
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Get the best image source for a given width
+  * Returns WebP if available, falls back to original
+  */
+ export function getOptimizedImageSrc(
+     basePath: string,
+     width?: number
+ ): string {
+     // Remove leading slash if present
+     const cleanPath = basePath.startsWith('/') ? basePath.slice(1) : basePath
+
+     // Determine which size to use
+     let sizeSuffix = ''
+     if (width) {
+         if (width &lt;= 400) {
+             sizeSuffix = '-thumb'
+         } else if (width &lt;= 800) {
+             sizeSuffix = '-medium'
+         } else if (width &lt;= 1200) {
+             sizeSuffix = '-large'
+         }
+     }
+
+     // Try WebP first, fallback to original
+     const webpPath = cleanPath.replace(/\.(jpg|jpeg|png)$/i, &#96;${sizeSuffix}.webp&#96;)
+     const originalPath = cleanPath.replace(/\.(jpg|jpeg|png)$/i, (match) =&gt; {
+         return sizeSuffix ? &#96;${sizeSuffix}${match}&#96; : match
+     })
+
+     // In a real implementation, you'd check if the file exists
+     // For now, we'll return the WebP path (browser will fallback if not found)
+     return &#96;/${webpPath}&#96;
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Generate srcset for responsive images
+  */
+ export function generateSrcSet(basePath: string): string {
+     const sizes = ['thumb', 'medium', 'large']
+     const widths = [400, 800, 1200]
+
+     return sizes
+         .map((size, index) =&gt; {
+             const webpPath = basePath.replace(/\.(jpg|jpeg|png)$/i, &#96;-${size}.webp&#96;)
+             return &#96;/${webpPath} ${widths[index]}w&#96;
+         })
+         .join(', ')
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Get image sizes attribute for responsive images
+  */
+ export function getImageSizes(breakpoints?: {
+     mobile?: number
+     tablet?: number
+     desktop?: number
+ }): string {
+     if (!breakpoints) {
+         return '(max-width: 768px) 100vw, (max-width: 1200px) 50vw, 33vw'
+     }
+
+     const { mobile = 100, tablet = 50, desktop = 33 } = breakpoints
+
+     return &#96;(max-width: 768px) ${mobile}vw, (max-width: 1200px) ${tablet}vw, ${desktop}vw&#96;
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Check if WebP is supported (for fallback logic)
+  */
+ export function isWebPSupported(): boolean {
+     if (typeof window === 'undefined') return true // Assume support on server
+
+     const canvas = document.createElement('canvas')
+     canvas.width = 1
+     canvas.height = 1
+     return canvas.toDataURL('image/webp').indexOf('data:image/webp') === 0
+ }
```

Creating a LazyImage component and enhancing lazy loading:

---

<tool-use data-tool-type="write" data-tool-name="write">

<details><summary>Tool use: **write** ‚Ä¢ Edit file: /Users/sagarsawuck/Projects/sagarsys.net-1/components/LazyImage.tsx</summary>

**Chunk 1** Lines added: 126, lines removed: 1

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,126 @@
-
+ 'use client'
+
+ import { useState, useRef, useEffect } from 'react'
+ import Image from 'next/image'
+
+ interface LazyImageProps {
+     src: string
+     alt: string
+     width?: number
+     height?: number
+     fill?: boolean
+     className?: string
+     priority?: boolean
+     placeholder?: 'blur' | 'empty'
+     blurDataURL?: string
+     sizes?: string
+     onLoad?: () =&gt; void
+     onError?: () =&gt; void
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * LazyImage component with intersection observer
+  *
+  * Only loads images when they're about to enter the viewport,
+  * reducing initial page load and improving performance.
+  */
+ export default function LazyImage({
+     src,
+     alt,
+     width,
+     height,
+     fill = false,
+     className = '',
+     priority = false,
+     placeholder = 'empty',
+     blurDataURL,
+     sizes,
+     onLoad,
+     onError,
+ }: LazyImageProps) {
+     const [isInView, setIsInView] = useState(priority)
+     const [isLoaded, setIsLoaded] = useState(false)
+     const imgRef = useRef&lt;HTMLDivElement&gt;(null)
+
+     useEffect(() =&gt; {
+         if (priority || isInView) return
+
+         const observer = new IntersectionObserver(
+             (entries) =&gt; {
+                 entries.forEach((entry) =&gt; {
+                     if (entry.isIntersecting) {
+                         setIsInView(true)
+                         observer.disconnect()
+                     }
+                 })
+             },
+             {
+                 rootMargin: '50px', // Start loading 50px before entering viewport
+                 threshold: 0.01,
+             }
+         )
+
+         if (imgRef.current) {
+             observer.observe(imgRef.current)
+         }
+
+         return () =&gt; {
+             observer.disconnect()
+         }
+     }, [priority, isInView])
+
+     const handleLoad = () =&gt; {
+         setIsLoaded(true)
+         onLoad?.()
+     }
+
+     const handleError = () =&gt; {
+         onError?.()
+     }
+
+     return (
+         &lt;div
+             ref={imgRef}
+             className={&#96;relative ${className}&#96;}
+             style={{
+                 width: fill ? '100%' : width,
+                 height: fill ? '100%' : height,
+             }}
+         &gt;
+             {/* Blur placeholder */}
+             {placeholder === 'blur' &amp;&amp; blurDataURL &amp;&amp; !isLoaded &amp;&amp; (
+                 &lt;div
+                     className="absolute inset-0 bg-cover bg-center blur-sm scale-110"
+                     style={{
+                         backgroundImage: &#96;url(${blurDataURL})&#96;,
+                     }}
+                 /&gt;
+             )}
+
+             {/* Loading skeleton */}
+             {!isLoaded &amp;&amp; !blurDataURL &amp;&amp; (
+                 &lt;div className="absolute inset-0 bg-slate-700 animate-pulse" /&gt;
+             )}
+
+             {/* Actual image */}
+             {isInView &amp;&amp; (
+                 &lt;Image
+                     src={src}
+                     alt={alt}
+                     width={fill ? undefined : width}
+                     height={fill ? undefined : height}
+                     fill={fill}
+                     className={&#96;transition-opacity duration-300 ${
+                         isLoaded ? 'opacity-100' : 'opacity-0'
+                     } ${className}&#96;}
+                     loading={priority ? 'eager' : 'lazy'}
+                     sizes={sizes}
+                     unoptimized
+                     onLoad={handleLoad}
+                     onError={handleError}
+                 /&gt;
+             )}
+         &lt;/div&gt;
+     )
+ }
+
```

```diff
+ /**
+  * Web Vitals measurement utilities
+  *
+  * Tracks Core Web Vitals and other performance metrics
+  */
+
+ import { onCLS, onFID, onFCP, onLCP, onTTFB, onINP, Metric } from 'web-vitals'
+
+ export interface WebVitalsReport {
+     name: string
+     value: number
+     rating: 'good' | 'needs-improvement' | 'poor'
+     delta: number
+     id: string
+     navigationType: string
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Web Vitals thresholds
+  */
+ export const VITALS_THRESHOLDS = {
+     LCP: { good: 2500, poor: 4000 }, // Largest Contentful Paint (ms)
+     FID: { good: 100, poor: 300 }, // First Input Delay (ms)
+     CLS: { good: 0.1, poor: 0.25 }, // Cumulative Layout Shift
+     FCP: { good: 1800, poor: 3000 }, // First Contentful Paint (ms)
+     TTFB: { good: 600, poor: 800 }, // Time to First Byte (ms)
+     INP: { good: 200, poor: 500 }, // Interaction to Next Paint (ms)
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Get rating for a metric value
+  */
+ export function getRating(
+     name: string,
+     value: number
+ ): 'good' | 'needs-improvement' | 'poor' {
+     const thresholds = VITALS_THRESHOLDS[name as keyof typeof VITALS_THRESHOLDS]
+     if (!thresholds) return 'good'
+
+     if (value &lt;= thresholds.good) return 'good'
+     if (value &lt;= thresholds.poor) return 'needs-improvement'
+     return 'poor'
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Format metric for logging/reporting
+  */
+ export function formatMetric(metric: Metric): WebVitalsReport {
+     return {
+         name: metric.name,
+         value: metric.value,
+         rating: getRating(metric.name, metric.value),
+         delta: metric.delta,
+         id: metric.id,
+         navigationType: metric.navigationType,
+     }
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Log metric to console (development only)
+  */
+ export function logMetric(metric: Metric) {
+     if (process.env.NODE_ENV !== 'development') return
+
+     const report = formatMetric(metric)
+     const emoji =
+         report.rating === 'good'
+             ? '‚úÖ'
+             : report.rating === 'needs-improvement'
+               ? '‚ö†Ô∏è'
+               : '‚ùå'
+
+     console.log(
+         &#96;${emoji} ${report.name}: ${Math.round(report.value)}ms (${report.rating})&#96;
+     )
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Send metric to analytics (optional)
+  *
+  * You can integrate with:
+  * - Google Analytics
+  * - Vercel Analytics
+  * - Custom analytics endpoint
+  */
+ export function sendToAnalytics(metric: Metric) {
+     const report = formatMetric(metric)
+
+     // Example: Send to custom endpoint
+     // fetch('/api/analytics', {
+     //     method: 'POST',
+     //     body: JSON.stringify(report),
+     //     headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
+     // })
+
+     // Example: Send to Google Analytics
+     // if (typeof window !== 'undefined' &amp;&amp; (window as any).gtag) {
+     //     (window as any).gtag('event', report.name, {
+     //         value: Math.round(report.value),
+     //         metric_rating: report.rating,
+     //         metric_id: report.id,
+     //         metric_delta: Math.round(report.delta),
+     //     })
+     // }
+
+     // For now, just log in development
+     logMetric(metric)
+ }
+
+ /**
+  * Initialize Web Vitals tracking
+  */
+ export function initWebVitals() {
+     if (typeof window === 'undefined') return
+
+     // Track all Core Web Vitals
+     onCLS(sendToAnalytics)
+     onFID(sendToAnalytics)
+     onFCP(sendToAnalytics)
+     onLCP(sendToAnalytics)
+     onTTFB(sendToAnalytics)
+     onINP(sendToAnalytics) // Interaction to Next Paint (replaces FID in the future)
+ }
+
```

### 3. Image optimization

-   Integrated optimization into build process
-   Script generates WebP versions and multiple sizes automatically

### 4. Lazy loading enhancements

-   Created `LazyImage` component with intersection observer

   `first-input-delay`

## Testing PWA - Step-by-Step Guide

### 1. Build the Application

First, build the production version (service worker is disabled in development):

```bash
npm run build
```

This generates:

-   Service worker file: `public/sw.js`
-   Workbox runtime: `public/workbox-*.js`
-   Static export in `build/` directory

### 2. Start the Production Server

```bash
npm run start
```

Or serve the static files directly:

```bash
npx serve build
```

The app should be available at `http://localhost:3000` (or the port shown).

### 3. Test Service Worker Registration

#### Using Chrome DevTools:

1. Open Chrome DevTools (F12 or Cmd+Option+I)
2. Go to Application tab
3. Check Service Workers:
    - Status should show "activated and is running"
    - Scope: `/`
    - Source: `sw.js`
4. Check Cache Storage:
    - You should see caches like:
        - `google-fonts`
        - `static-image-assets`
        - `static-js-assets`
        - `pages`
        - etc.

#### Using Console:

Open the browser console and check:

```javascript
// Check if service worker is registered
navigator.serviceWorker.getRegistrations().then((registrations) => {
    console.log('Service Workers:', registrations)
})

// Check service worker state
navigator.serviceWorker.ready.then((registration) => {
    console.log('SW Ready:', registration)
})
```

### 4. Test Offline Functionality

#### Method 1: Chrome DevTools Network Throttling

1. Open DevTools ‚Üí Network tab
2. Set throttling to "Offline"
3. Refresh the page
4. Expected: The page should load from cache
5. Navigate to different pages
6. Expected: Cached pages should work; uncached pages show the offline fallback

#### Method 2: Disable Network in DevTools

1. DevTools ‚Üí Network tab
2. Check "Disable cache" (unchecked)
3. Right-click the refresh button ‚Üí "Empty Cache and Hard Reload"
4. Then check "Offline" checkbox
5. Navigate around the site

#### Method 3: Test Offline Fallback

1. Go offline (using DevTools or system network settings)
2. Navigate to a page that wasn't cached
3. Expected: Should show `offline.html` or a cached version

### 5. Test PWA Installability

#### Desktop (Chrome/Edge):

1. Look for the install icon in the address bar
2. Or check Application ‚Üí Manifest:
    - Should show manifest details
    - "Add to homescreen" should be available
3. Click "Install" and verify it installs as a standalone app

#### Mobile Testing:

1. Build and deploy to a server (or use ngrok/tunneling for local testing)
2. Open on a mobile device
3. iOS Safari: Share ‚Üí Add to Home Screen
4. Android Chrome: Should show install banner automatically

### 6. Verify Cache Strategies

Test different resource types:

```javascript
// In browser console, check what's cached
caches.keys().then((keys) => {
    console.log('Cache names:', keys)
    keys.forEach((key) => {
        caches.open(key).then((cache) => {
            cache.keys().then((requests) => {
                console.log(`Cache "${key}" has ${requests.length} items`)
            })
        })
    })
})
```

### 7. Test Cache Updates

1. Make a change to your code
2. Rebuild: `npm run build`
3. Reload the page
4. Check DevTools ‚Üí Application ‚Üí Service Workers
5. You should see "Update" available
6. Click "Update" to activate the new service worker

### 8. Manual Testing Checklist

-   [ ] Service worker registers on first visit
-   [ ] Service worker activates immediately (`skipWaiting: true`)
-   [ ] Static assets (JS, CSS) are cached
-   [ ] Images are cached with CacheFirst strategy
-   [ ] Pages are cached with NetworkFirst strategy
-   [ ] Offline mode shows cached content
-   [ ] Offline fallback page appears for uncached routes
-   [ ] PWA manifest is valid (check Application ‚Üí Manifest)
-   [ ] App is installable (desktop and mobile)
-   [ ] Service worker updates correctly on rebuild

### 9. Debugging Tips

If the service worker doesn't register:

1. Check console for errors
2. Verify `sw.js` exists in `public/` after build
3. Check that you're testing in production mode (not dev)
4. Clear all caches and service workers:
    ```javascript
    // In console
    caches.keys().then((keys) => keys.forEach((key) => caches.delete(key)))
    navigator.serviceWorker
        .getRegistrations()
        .then((regs) => regs.forEach((reg) => reg.unregister()))
    ```
5. Hard refresh (Cmd+Shift+R / Ctrl+Shift+R)

### 10. Lighthouse PWA Audit

Run a Lighthouse audit:

1. DevTools ‚Üí Lighthouse tab
2. Select "Progressive Web App"
3. Run audit
4. Should score 100/100 for PWA if everything is configured correctly

### Quick Test Script

You can also add this to your browser console for quick testing:

```javascript
// Quick PWA test
async function testPWA() {
    console.log('=== PWA Test ===')

    // Service Worker
    const sw = await navigator.serviceWorker.getRegistration()
    console.log('SW Registered:', !!sw)
    if (sw) console.log('SW State:', sw.active?.state)

    // Caches
    const cacheNames = await caches.keys()
    console.log('Caches:', cacheNames)
    console.log('Total caches:', cacheNames.length)

    // Manifest
    const manifest = await fetch('/manifest.json').then((r) => r.json())
    console.log('Manifest:', manifest)

    // Installability
    console.log(
        'Installable:',
        'serviceWorker' in navigator && 'PushManager' in window
    )
}

testPWA()
```

Note: The service worker is disabled in development mode
(`disable: process.env.NODE_ENV === 'development'`), so you must test with a
production build.

If you encounter issues, share the error messages or console output.

Server is running. The issue was that `next start` doesn't work with static
exports (`output: 'export'`). Static exports generate HTML files that need a
static file server.

## Fix Applied

1. Installed `serve` as a dev dependency
2. Updated the `start` script from `next start` to `serve build -p 3000`
3. Server is running at `http://localhost:3000`

## Summary

**Problem**: `next start` requires a server-side build (`.next` directory), but
static exports only generate static files in the `build` directory.

**Solution**: Use `serve` to serve the static files from the `build` directory
instead of `next start`.

You can now test the PWA at `http://localhost:3000`. The service worker should
register, and you can test offline functionality using the steps from the
previous guide.

To stop the server, press `Ctrl+C` in the terminal where it's running, or kill
the background process.

It uses patented technology that extracts content from a standard PDF file to convert it into HTML support that fits any screen.\n\n## Live Examples\n\n- [Publicis Groupe - 2018 CSR Report](https://publicis-groupe.publispeak.com/2018-registration-document/page/C1/)\n- [Airliquide - 2018 Annual report](https://airliquide.publispeak.com/2018-annual-report/page/C1/)\n- [BNP Paribas - 2018 Integrated report](http://integrated-report.bnpparibas/2018/doc/article/C1/)\n- [L'Oreal - 2019 Letter to shareholders](https://loreal-finance.publispeak.com/letter-to-shareholders-73/doc/article/1/)\n\n## My Role\n\nTogether with a team of 3 developers and a CTO, our role was to migrate an older flash version of PubliSpeak to modern web technologies, accessible across multiple devices (screen sizes) and within accessibility standards. As a senior frontend developer, my task was to use CSS3 and Angular to make this work, while interacting with and integrating the backend APIs.\n\n## Key Challenges\n\n- **Accessibility First**: Due to accessibility requirements, we could not use existing plugins/libraries. This implied developing our own in-house libraries, such as an infinite scroll engine, a carousel, and others.\n\n- **Multi-tenant Platform**: Each client could customize the platform to match their branding. I had to introduce CSS variables to change the look and feel of the whole platform.\n\n- **Performance Optimization**: Some PDFs are 500+ pages long. The infinite scroll engine was responsible for switching between image representation to HTML view for pages in focus, with lazy loading of HTML chunks.\n\n- **Fully Responsive Design**: Focus on UI/UX coupled with strict accessibility constraints.\n\n- **Team Growth**: Formation and training of junior developers as the company expanded.\n"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"27:Tc1e,"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"\n## Overview\n\nActievandedag is a high-traffic eCommerce platform built with React and Next.js, serving millions of users daily. The platform focuses on delivering exceptional user experiences through optimized performance, engaging interfaces, and seamless shopping experiences.\n\n## My Role\n\nAs a Full-stack JavaScript Developer at Talpa eCommerce, I worked on React/Next.js development for this high-traffic eCommerce platform. My focus was on enhancing user engagement, optimizing performance, and improving developer productivity across the team.\n\n**Key Responsibilities:**\n\n- Developed and maintained React/Next.js frontend features for millions of users\n- Built REST APIs using Fastify and Node.js for seamless backend integration\n- Optimized application performance to handle high traffic loads\n- Migrated codebase to new React versions while maintaining zero downtime\n- Improved code maintainability and developer experience across the team\n- Managed cloud infrastructure deployments on AWS using Docker and Kubernetes\n- Implemented comprehensive Jest test suites for code reliability\n\n## Key Challenges\n\n- **High-Traffic Performance**: Optimizing React/Next.js application to handle millions of users with minimal latency and maximum uptime. This required careful attention to code splitting, lazy loading, and efficient state management.\n\n- **Code Maintainability**: Improving code quality and developer experience across the team while maintaining fast delivery cycles. Introduced best practices, code reviews, and reusable component libraries.\n\n- **Full-Stack Integration**: Building REST APIs with Fastify/Node.js that seamlessly integrate with React frontend features. Ensured consistent data flow and error handling across the stack.\n\n- **React Migration**: Successfully migrating to new React versions while maintaining backward compatibility and zero downtime. This involved careful planning, incremental updates, and thorough testing.\n\n- **Cloud Infrastructure**: Managing deployments on AWS with Docker and Kubernetes for scalable, reliable operations. Implemented CI/CD pipelines with GitHub Actions for automated deployments.\n\n- **Testing \u0026 Quality**: Implementing comprehensive Jest test suites to ensure code reliability and prevent regressions. Achieved high test coverage while maintaining development velocity.\n\n## Technical Highlights\n\n- **Frontend**: React, Next.js, TypeScript, Redux for state management\n- **Backend**: Fastify, Node.js for REST API development\n- **Testing**: Jest for comprehensive test coverage\n- **Infrastructure**: AWS, Docker, Kubernetes for scalable deployments\n- **CI/CD**: GitHub Actions for automated workflows\n- **Performance**: Optimized for high-traffic scenarios with millions of users\n\n## Impact\n\n- Enhanced UX and performance, driving higher user engagement\n- Improved code maintainability and developer experience across the team\n- Built robust REST APIs alongside frontend features for seamless integration\n- Successfully migrated to new React versions with zero downtime\n- Established scalable cloud infrastructure for reliable operations\n"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"28:T49d,"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"\n## Overview\n\nRework of a real-estate website for Kaufman \u0026 Broad, a publicly traded real estate development and construction company headquartered in France. Users can search for properties, learn about new opportunities \u0026 promos, and find useful information to guide them through their property acquisition journey.\n\n## My Role\n\nAs the frontend lead in a team of four developers, my responsibilities included:\n\n- Setup project architecture\n- Automate developers' workflow using Gulp/webpack\n- Establish development guidelines\n- Analyze requirements \u0026 make time estimates\n- Setup foundation for core project modules\n- Ensure code meets standards through code reviews\n- Train junior developers\n- Liaise with backend to establish API contracts\n- Liaise with UX designer to discuss feasibility\n- Participate in client meetings \u0026 development\n\n## Key Challenges\n\n- Fast-paced client demands with changing requirements and design\n- Integration of external service providers (e.g., 3D guided tours)\n- Migration from legacy codebase with unrealistic client expectations\n- Tight deadlines\n- Cross-platform and cross-device considerations\n- Onboarding and training newcomers to the project\n"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"29:T53b,"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"\n## Overview\n\nDesktop-based \"mini-game\" applications for interactive kiosks. Applications developed around data collection concept. Users participate in mini-games for a chance to win prizes while agreeing to submit data or answer survey questions. Collected data is extracted for marketing purposes.\n\n## My Role\n\nAs a fullstack developer, I participated in the full lifecycle of the project - from design to deployment \u0026 support. Together with my frontend colleague, we chose the tech stack and developed a generic reusable library for quick application building.\n\nResponsibilities:\n\n- Full application development (frontend + backend)\n- Remote deployment and testing on kiosks\n- Live support and debugging\n- Data export in CSV format\n\n## Key Challenges\n\n- **Remote Debugging**: Live support worldwide, working odd hours due to timezone differences\n- **Tactile UI/UX**: No physical keyboard, designed emulated keyboard interface\n- **Peripheral Devices**: Integration with printers, QR/barcode scanners\n- **Admin Interface**: Hidden mechanism to access administration for debugging, reprinting tickets, exporting data\n- **Deployment**: Standard process to build and deploy Electron app with required peripheral device drivers\n- **Tight Deadlines**: Applications delivered for specific events (Christmas, festivals) with no room for delays\n"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"2a:Te34,"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"\n## Overview\n\nFounded in 1995, Biocom is a wholesale distributor of pharmaceutical products in Mauritius, the region, and its global network of healthcare professionals. Biocom's major clients involve medical organizations, pharmacies, governmental, and embodied institutions.\n\nThe website represents a complete digital transformation for a company that had been operating for 25 years, requiring a rebranding to transition to the web while maintaining their core values of simplicity and professionalism.\n\n## My Role\n\nAs a fullstack developer and designer, my role was to assist the client from start to finish throughout the project's lifecycle: conception, prototyping, design, content recommendation, development, deployment, hosting, optimization \u0026 SEO (Search Engine Optimization), and accessibility.\n\n**Key Responsibilities:**\n\n- Complete project lifecycle management from conception to deployment\n- Brand identity design and digital transformation strategy\n- Full-stack development using React, Next.js, and Material UI\n- AWS infrastructure setup (S3 + CloudFront) for global performance\n- SEO optimization and accessibility compliance\n- Progressive Web App (PWA) implementation\n\n## Key Challenges\n\n- **Brand Identity Creation**: Project was started from scratch. Biocom has been operating for 25 years and needed a rebranding to transition to the web. It was both challenging and fun to figure out how to tell their brand story effectively - with the principle guideline from the director - simplicity. We went through a lot of brainstorming in order to create a digital identity for Biocom.\n\n- **Modern React Architecture**: React was used as the UI framework in order to create the subtle user interactions on the website. React Material UI complements this choice by giving the website a clean look. Also note that from a technical perspective, the website uses the latest React hook APIs.\n\n- **Static Site Optimization**: In order to make the website as lightweight as possible, it was pre-rendered and statically hosted. This implies careful use of browser APIs within the source code.\n\n- **Contact Form Integration**: A contact form within the static website was an issue that needed to be resolved. This required creative solutions to handle form submissions without a traditional backend.\n\n- **Global Performance**: The website is hosted on an AWS S3 bucket, and cached/served by worldwide AWS CloudFront distributions to optimize load times for viewers throughout the world.\n\n- **Web Standards \u0026 Accessibility**: The website has a score of 80+ on Google Lighthouse - it is optimized to modern web standards, including accessibility, SEO, and PWA (Progressive Web App).\n\n- **Cross-Platform Testing**: Responsive design and extreme focus on user experience (UX) across devices and platforms - heavy testing on mobile phones, tablets and desktop, on Windows, Mac, Android \u0026 iPhone (Safari, IE, Firefox, Chrome, Opera).\n\n## Technical Highlights\n\n- **Frontend**: React JS with Material UI, Next.js for static generation\n- **Styling**: CSS Preprocessor (SCSS) for maintainable stylesheets\n- **Infrastructure**: AWS S3 for hosting, CloudFront for global CDN\n- **APIs**: Google Maps API integration\n- **Performance**: 80+ Lighthouse score, PWA capabilities\n- **Accessibility**: WCAG compliant, optimized for all users\n\n## Impact\n\n- Successfully rebranded a 25-year-old company for the digital age\n- Created a modern, accessible, and performant web presence\n- Achieved 80+ Lighthouse score across all metrics\n- Implemented global CDN for optimal performance worldwide\n- Delivered a complete solution from design to deployment\n\n"])&lt;/script&gt;&lt;script&gt;self.__next_f.push([1,"11:[\"$\",\"section\",null,{\"id\":\"projects\",\"className\":\"py-20 md:py-32 px-6 relative\",\"children\":[\"$\",\"div\",null,{\"className\":\"max-w-7xl mx-auto\",\"children\":[[\"$\",\"$Lc\",null,{\"title\":\"Projects\",\"subtitle\":\"A collection of my professional and personal work\"}],[\"$\",\"$L25\",null,{\"projects\":[{\"frontmatter\":{\"title\":\"PubliSpeak\",\"titleLink\":\"https://www.ipedis.com/en/publispeak\",\"description\":\"First PDF document virtualization solution that is fully accessible (WCAG 2.1 compliant)\",\"tech\":[\"Angular\",\"TypeScript\",\"CSS3\",\"Symfony\"],\"featured\":true,\"liveUrl\":\"https://www.ipedis.com/en/publispeak\",\"client\":\"Ipedis\",\"clientLink\":\"https://www.ipedis.com/\",\"role\":\"Senior frontend developer\",\"roleDescription\":\"Together with a team of 3 developers and a CTO, our role was to migrate an older flash version of PubliSpeak to modern web technologies, accessible across multiple devices (screen sizes) and within accessibility standards. Created a `ServiceWorkerRegistration` component that manually registers the
service worker. It includes instrumentation to log:

-   Whether the service worker API is available
-   Registration attempts and results
-   Service worker state changes
-   Cache storage status
-   Any errors during registration

The component is added to the layout and will run on page load. After you test,
share:

1. What you see in DevTools ‚Üí Application ‚Üí Service Workers
2. Any console errors
3. Whether `/sw.js` loads in the Network tab
4. The contents of the debug log file

This will help identify why the service worker isn't registering or caching.

## Summary

**Problem**: Service worker wasn't registering because `next-pwa`'s
auto-registration doesn't work with static export mode.

**Solution**: Created a manual `ServiceWorkerRegistration` component that
registers the service worker on page load. The component:

-   Checks for service worker support
-   Registers `/sw.js` with scope `/`
-   Handles registration errors gracefully
-   Listens for service worker updates

The service worker should now register correctly, and the cache-first strategy
will populate cache storage for offline functionality.

Added instrumentation to trace why cache storage isn't populating. Hypotheses:

-   A: Service worker registers but doesn't activate (stuck in
    installing/waiting)
-   B: Service worker activates but precaching fails silently
-   C: Service worker activates but runtime caching isn't triggered (resources
    not requested)
-   D: Caches are created under different names than expected
-   E: Service worker activation fails with an error

The instrumentation logs:

-   Initial cache state
-   Service worker registration and state changes
-   Cache storage checks at 1s, 3s, 5s, and 10s
-   Cache names and their contents
